keyTakeAways: Curtis Sliwa, a long-time figure in NYC politics known for eccentric behavior, is facing mounting pressure to drop out of the mayoral race to allow a one-on-one contest between Zohran Mamdani and Andrew Cuomo.
Sliwa is criticized by both Andrew Cuomo and key Republican allies for splitting the anti-Mamdani vote, with supporters like Bill Ackman and media figures accusing him of being a liability.
Despite pressure, Sliwa has publicly stated he will not exit the race and has made sharp, progressive critiques of billionaires and elites, echoing Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani.
Zohran Mamdani, a self-described democratic socialist, has gained significant support and polling leads, though concerns remain about his views on Israel and police.
Andrew Cuomo has dismissed Sliwa as a 'shock jock' and criticized him for not engaging on the campaign trail, while accusing Sliwa of being a perennial candidate who fails to energize voters.
Supporters of Sliwa, including Rudy Giuliani and Manhattan GOP chair Andrea Catsimatidis, have reaffirmed their backing, signaling party unity behind him despite internal dissent.
Media outlets like The New York Post and The New York Daily News have urged Sliwa to drop out, citing a need to consolidate the anti-Mamdani vote.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In the midst of a pivotal mayoral race in New York City, Curtis Sliwa, the Republican nominee, faces intense pressure to drop out of the race to allow for a direct contest between Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani and independent candidate Andrew Cuomo. Sliwa, known for his eccentric style and sharp critiques of elites, has drawn criticism from both Cuomo and key allies, who argue that his candidacy splits the anti-Mamdani vote. While figures like Rudy Giuliani and the Manhattan GOP chair have publicly backed Sliwa, others—including WABC owner John Catsimatidis and major media outlets like the New York Post and Daily News—have urged him to exit, citing a need to unify the opposition. Sliwa has dismissed these calls, maintaining his candidacy and echoing Mamdani’s progressive messaging. As the debate approaches, the political stakes center on whether Sliwa’s persistence will energize the Republican base or fragment the electorate, ultimately shaping the outcome of one of the most consequential mayoral elections in decades.
title: The NYC mayoral debate’s key question: What will Curtis Sliwa say, or do, next?
